title: How to Design an Ugly Sweater Using Stickers

steps.headline: Set a piece of watercolor paper in either orientation.
steps.description: Decide if you want to show one, two or three sweaters. If you make two, you might include a long-sleeved sweater and a sleeveless vest.

steps.headline: Look at some actual sweaters for ideas.
Discuss ugly sweaters.
steps.description: If you are working with a group, ask participants to tell about ugly sweaters;  Who owned one?, Where it came from?, How often has it been worn? What reactions did the wearer get? Ask the person to describe it.

steps.headline: Draw the outline of the sweater of your choice on the watercolor paper in pencil.
steps.description: Make the sweater(s) large enough to almost fill the space.

steps.headline: Get ideas flowing and decide on your theme for the decorations you will be putting on the sweater.
steps.description: You will be using stickers for the graphics, so buy a pack of stickers that represent some of your favorite things. As to theme, get whatever interests you. Or try something new and different that will just be ugly. If in doubt, Christmas stickers are always a good choice.

steps.headline: Divide the space within the sweater into 7-8 shapes, using a pencil to draw the lines.
steps.description: Draw around the sweaters own design lines, the neckline (“V“ or rounded), cuffs and bottom.

steps.headline: Paint the shapes on the sweaters with watercolor.
steps.description:
Any color is fine, but often the Christmas classic of primary red and green are highlighted. Anything goes, though, remember it is an “ugly” sweater you are aiming to make. Remember that there are many shade of red and green. Dilute any color for weak shades of that color. Red diluted is pink, blue is "baby" blue, violet becomes lavender, etc. This will give you more color options. Any color is fine, it is an ugly sweater you are doing. Paint all the spaces and let the paint dry, using a hair dryer, if you wish.

steps.headline: Refine the design by outlining it in black marker.
Let the designing begin by using stickers to fill in the spaces.
steps.description: Use as many or as few as you wish. Do repeat patterns around the neck, wrists and waistline of the sweater. Add glitter glue, felt self-stick-on images, glitter and jewels. There is no limit to how much you decorate the sweaters. Think of this slogan: “A lot is never enough.”  When it comes to ugly sweaters, let yourself go and pile on the embellishments.

steps.headline: Hang this art representation of an ugly sweater in a prominent place for all to appreciate.
steps.description: Write comments people make about it on note paper and when you take the art piece down, tape the comments to the back to remember in years to come the reactions to it.

tyn: Watercolor paper, a heavy stock, any size
Sharpie markers, or other colored markers optional
Glitter glue, glitter, felt stickers, etc.

Set a piece of watercolor paper in either orientation. Decide if you want to show one, two or three sweaters. If you make two, you might include a long-sleeved sweater and a sleeveless vest. Look at some actual sweaters for ideas. Or, Google: Ugly Christmas Sweaters. Discuss ugly sweaters. If you are working with a group, ask participants to tell about ugly sweaters; Who owned one?, Where it came from?, How often has it been worn? What reactions did the wearer get? Ask the person to describe it. Draw the outline of the sweater of your choice on the watercolor paper in pencil. Make the sweater(s) large enough to almost fill the space. Get ideas flowing and decide on your theme for the decorations you will be putting on the sweater. You will be using stickers for the graphics, so buy a pack of stickers that represent some of your favorite things. As to theme, get whatever interests you. Or try something new and different that will just be ugly. If in doubt, Christmas stickers are always a good choice. Divide the space within the sweater into 7-8 shapes, using a pencil to draw the lines. Draw around the sweaters own design lines, the neckline (“V“ or rounded), cuffs and bottom. Paint the shapes on the sweaters with watercolor. Any color is fine, but often the Christmas classic of primary red and green are highlighted. Anything goes, though, remember it is an “ugly” sweater you are aiming to make. Remember that there are many shade of red and green.
